headline.main: 6 Members of Panel on Smoking Have Ties to Tobacco Group

docs.lead_paragraph: Six scientists on an Environmental Protection Agency panel on smoking, including its chairman, have ties to a tobacco industry research group, but the environmental agency says that is no problem. The 16-member panel's task is to assure the accuracy and objectivity of two E.P.A. studies not yet published concerning the health effects of second-hand cigarette smoke. In addition to the six members with ties to the tobacco research organization, a seventh member of the panel was appointed at the urging of the Philip Morris Companies, officials of the environmental agency said Thursday.

headline.main: High Blood Pressure: An Overtreated Condition?

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans are being overtreated for the mildest form of high blood pressure, critics say. They blame a government health strategy that they call wasteful, expensive and possibly dangerous. The critics, who are experts in high blood pressure at American medical school, also say it is urgent to find a way to reduce the huge number of people who risk side effects from drug treatment. A crucial goal is to learn how to identify those who are most susceptible to the strokes and other complications of high blood pressure so they can be treated, while eliminating drug treatment for the many others who would not benefit.
